p: Above-ground population size in both Cypripedium populations was roughly stable at the beginning of the study, but declined towards 2010. The number of emergent plants in the Ophrys population was low until 1991, after which it increased nearly sixfold, and then began a slow decline to the end of the study, in 2006. Estimated numbers of living juveniles + adults (not including seedlings) ranged between years from 330 to 575 in C. parviflorum, from 46 to 71 in C. candidum, and from 41 to 657 in Ophrys. Estimates of annual deterministic λ ranged from 0.971 to 1.138 (mean ± 1 s.e. = 1.056 ± 0.011) in C. parviflorum, from 0.919 to 1.144 (mean ± 1 s.e. = 1.062 ± 0.013) in C. candidum, and from 0.869 to 1.123 (mean ±1 s.e. = 0.992 ± 0.015) in Ophrys.
